data.question: Let A B, , and C be square matrices of order n.If A is non-singular and AC = BC, then A = B
data.point1: But what happens here is I've got a times a inverse, and we know by definition a a inverse is equal to e, the identity element. And same thing on the left, right? So I've got the identity b is equal to the identity times c, and the identity element times an element is just the element itself. So we get that b equals c. In other words, this theorem holds true.
